cell.html: Park lies on a glacial moraine with deep ravines that drop 300 feet (91.44 m) down to the St. Croix River.
cell.text: Park lies on a glacial moraine with deep ravines that drop 300 feet (91.44 m) down to the St. Croix River.

cell.html: Park contains of 1.5 miles (2.41 km) of whitewater rapids and an historic quarry.
cell.text: Park contains of 1.5 miles (2.41 km) of whitewater rapids and an historic quarry.

cell.html: Park is located just south of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness .
cell.text: Park is located just south of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness .

cell.html: The narrow valley carved by a trout stream showcases the rugged topography of the Driftless Area .
cell.text: The narrow valley carved by a trout stream showcases the rugged topography of the Driftless Area .

cell.html: The Big Bog, the largest peatland in the Lower U.S. [6] , sits on the southeast side of glacial Lake Agassiz .
cell.text: The Big Bog, the largest peatland in the Lower U.S. [6] , sits on the southeast side of glacial Lake Agassiz .

cell.html: The park is located on the south end of glacial Lake Agassiz.
cell.text: The park is located on the south end of glacial Lake Agassiz.

cell.html: The park is named after a linear escarpment of Precambrian quartzite bedrock .
cell.text: The park is named after a linear escarpment of Precambrian quartzite bedrock .

cell.html: The prairie within the park is judged to be one of the largest and best of the state's prairie preserves.
cell.text: The prairie within the park is judged to be one of the largest and best of the state's prairie preserves.

cell.html: Thirteen buildings and structures are listed on the National Register of Historic Places .
cell.text: Thirteen buildings and structures are listed on the National Register of Historic Places .

cell.html: Park is named after State Senator James A. Carley, who donated the land.
cell.text: Park is named after State Senator James A. Carley, who donated the land.

cell.html: Park is connected to the Superior Hiking Trail and North Shore State Trail.
cell.text: Park is connected to the Superior Hiking Trail and North Shore State Trail.

cell.html: Contains the restored home of Charles August Lindbergh , Congressman and the father of the famous aviator , Charles Lindbergh .
cell.text: Contains the restored home of Charles August Lindbergh , Congressman and the father of the famous aviator , Charles Lindbergh .

cell.html: Interprets the site of Old Crow Wing , an important trading settlement.
cell.text: Interprets the site of Old Crow Wing , an important trading settlement.

cell.html: Chain of small lakes and streams, filled pit mines
cell.text: Chain of small lakes and streams, filled pit mines

cell.html: The Cuyuna Range was the last of Minnesota's three major iron ranges to be discovered and mined.
cell.text: The Cuyuna Range was the last of Minnesota's three major iron ranges to be discovered and mined.

cell.html: Park is named after Father Louis Hennepin , a priest who visited the area with a French expedition in 1680.
cell.text: Park is named after Father Louis Hennepin , a priest who visited the area with a French expedition in 1680.

cell.html: Park is named after Charles Eugene Flandrau , an important figure in the Battles of New Ulm during the Dakota War of 1862 .
cell.text: Park is named after Charles Eugene Flandrau , an important figure in the Battles of New Ulm during the Dakota War of 1862 .
South Branch Root River and tributaries

cell.html: Park contains Mystery Cave, the longest cave in the state that is open to the public.
cell.text: Park contains Mystery Cave, the longest cave in the state that is open to the public.

cell.html: Park preserves Fort Ridgely , which is notable for its use during the Dakota War of 1862.
cell.text: Park preserves Fort Ridgely , which is notable for its use during the Dakota War of 1862.

cell.html: Park contains historic Fort Snelling , which was built in 1819.
cell.text: Park contains historic Fort Snelling , which was built in 1819.

cell.html: The sons of Franz Jevne, a lawyer , offered to donate land to the state for use as a park on the condition that it be named after their father.
cell.text: The sons of Franz Jevne, a lawyer , offered to donate land to the state for use as a park on the condition that it be named after their father.

cell.html: Park is home to 260 species of birds for part or all of the year.
cell.text: Park is home to 260 species of birds for part or all of the year.

cell.html: Formerly the site of a large garden created by Native Americans taught by La Vérendrye who explored the area.
cell.text: Formerly the site of a large garden created by Native Americans taught by La Vérendrye who explored the area.
George H. Crosby Manitou State Park

cell.html: 47°30′22″N 91°06′33″W ﻿ / ﻿ 47.506018 , -91.109045 ﻿ ( George H Crosby Manitou State Park )
cell.text: 47°30′22″N 91°06′33″W ﻿ / ﻿ 47.506018 , -91.109045 ﻿ ( George H Crosby Manitou State Park )

cell.html: Park contains many undisturbed miles of fir , cedar , spruce , and northern hardwoods. Park is geared towards backpackers .
cell.text: Park contains many undisturbed miles of fir , cedar , spruce , and northern hardwoods. Park is geared towards backpackers .

cell.html: Park contains many glacial landforms, including rolling glacial hills unlike others in the state, created by the Wisconsonian glaciation .
cell.text: Park contains many glacial landforms, including rolling glacial hills unlike others in the state, created by the Wisconsonian glaciation .

cell.html: During the 1950s, when it was a resort, former presidents Dwight Eisenhower and Richard Nixon were guests at Glendalough.
cell.text: During the 1950s, when it was a resort, former presidents Dwight Eisenhower and Richard Nixon were guests at Glendalough.

cell.html: The park includes Lake Superior shoreline, five waterfalls, Gooseberry River and gorge, an agate Beach and the Picnic Lava Flow.
cell.text: The park includes Lake Superior shoreline, five waterfalls, Gooseberry River and gorge, an agate Beach and the Picnic Lava Flow.

cell.html: Park contains a 120 foot (37 meter) waterfall , the tallest in the state shared on a border.
cell.text: Park contains a 120 foot (37 meter) waterfall , the tallest in the state shared on a border.

cell.html: Features 500-foot (150 m) high bluffs and steep " goat prairies " Formerly named O.L. Kipp State Park.
cell.text: Features 500-foot (150 m) high bluffs and steep " goat prairies " Formerly named O.L. Kipp State Park.
Hayes Lake, North Fork Roseau River

cell.html: Hayes Lake was created for the park by damming the Roseau River. In the Glacial Lake Agassiz lake bed.
cell.text: Hayes Lake was created for the park by damming the Roseau River. In the Glacial Lake Agassiz lake bed.

cell.html: Well preserved historic mine buildings that are on the National Register of Historic Places
cell.text: Well preserved historic mine buildings that are on the National Register of Historic Places

cell.html: This was the first park in the United States to span two states ( Minnesota and Wisconsin ).
cell.text: This was the first park in the United States to span two states ( Minnesota and Wisconsin ).

cell.html: Minnesota's oldest state park. Lake Itasca is the source of the Mississippi River .
cell.text: Minnesota's oldest state park. Lake Itasca is the source of the Mississippi River .

cell.html: Features rustic style historical structures and swinging bridge built by the CCC between 1933 and 1942.
cell.text: Features rustic style historical structures and swinging bridge built by the CCC between 1933 and 1942.

cell.html: Features three steep river bluffs named Faith, Hope, and Charity.
cell.text: Features three steep river bluffs named Faith, Hope, and Charity.
Judge C. R. Magney State Park

cell.html: Contains "Devil's Kettle" a large glacial kettle into which half of the Brule River disappears.
cell.text: Contains "Devil's Kettle" a large glacial kettle into which half of the Brule River disappears.

cell.html: Park is on the Coteau des Prairies .
cell.text: Park is on the Coteau des Prairies .

cell.html: Lac qui Parle , Minnesota and Lac qui Parle Rivers
cell.text: Lac qui Parle , Minnesota and Lac qui Parle Rivers

cell.html: Lac qui Parle is a widening in the Minnesota River, stopover for thousands of migrating waterfowl. Park contains 3 buildings on the NRHP .
cell.text: Lac qui Parle is a widening in the Minnesota River, stopover for thousands of migrating waterfowl. Park contains 3 buildings on the NRHP .

cell.html: In addition to recreational lakeshore, the park features a boardwalk trail out into a spruce-tamarack bog.
cell.text: In addition to recreational lakeshore, the park features a boardwalk trail out into a spruce-tamarack bog.
Lake Bronson, South Branch Two Rivers

cell.html: Hayes lake was created for the park, by damming the Two Rivers. In the Glacial Lake Agassiz lake bed. Park is on the NRHP.
cell.text: Hayes lake was created for the park, by damming the Two Rivers. In the Glacial Lake Agassiz lake bed. Park is on the NRHP.

cell.html: Five buildings on the NRHP. In a hardwood transition zone between prairies and coniferous forest.
cell.text: Five buildings on the NRHP. In a hardwood transition zone between prairies and coniferous forest.

cell.html: Minnesota's oldest continuous recreation area. Lake Louise was created by damming the Little Iowa River.
cell.text: Minnesota's oldest continuous recreation area. Lake Louise was created by damming the Little Iowa River.

cell.html: Lightly developed to provide a wilderness area near Minneapolis-Saint Paul .
cell.text: Lightly developed to provide a wilderness area near Minneapolis-Saint Paul .

cell.html: Eight historic resources within the state park are on the NRHP. Located on the Coteau des Prairies , the park was once treeless prairie.
cell.text: Eight historic resources within the state park are on the NRHP. Located on the Coteau des Prairies , the park was once treeless prairie.

cell.html: The park preserves a pre-contact habitation site that was occupied in two different periods (650–900 CE and 1450–1650) in a forest/prairie transition zone.
cell.text: The park preserves a pre-contact habitation site that was occupied in two different periods (650–900 CE and 1450–1650) in a forest/prairie transition zone.

cell.html: Highways' Magazine rated the beach on Sturgeon Lake one of the top 17 beaches in North America.
cell.text: Highways' Magazine rated the beach on Sturgeon Lake one of the top 17 beaches in North America.

cell.html: Park contains 19 identified archaeological sites. The earliest site shows evidence of copper tool manufacture. The Kathio site is a National Historic Landmark .
cell.text: Park contains 19 identified archaeological sites. The earliest site shows evidence of copper tool manufacture. The Kathio site is a National Historic Landmark .

cell.html: Contains Seppmann windmill which is on the NRHP. Minneopa Creek and its waterfalls are the major features that attract visitors.
cell.text: Contains Seppmann windmill which is on the NRHP. Minneopa Creek and its waterfalls are the major features that attract visitors.

cell.html: Hennepin , Dakota , Scott , Carver , Sibley , and Le Sueur
cell.text: Hennepin , Dakota , Scott , Carver , Sibley , and Le Sueur

cell.html: The sections of this non-contiguous park are interspersed with units of the Minnesota Valley National Wildlife Refuge in the valley formed by Glacial River Warren .
cell.text: The sections of this non-contiguous park are interspersed with units of the Minnesota Valley National Wildlife Refuge in the valley formed by Glacial River Warren .

cell.html: Established as a memorial to settlers who died in the Dakota War of 1862 .
cell.text: Established as a memorial to settlers who died in the Dakota War of 1862 .

cell.html: The Moose Lake Agate and Geological Interpretive Center is located in the park. Contains an exhibition of Minnesota's state gemstone, the Lake Superior agate , and contains displays on rocks, minerals and geology of Minnesota .
cell.text: The Moose Lake Agate and Geological Interpretive Center is located in the park. Contains an exhibition of Minnesota's state gemstone, the Lake Superior agate , and contains displays on rocks, minerals and geology of Minnesota .

cell.html: Two islands protected from prairie fires by the surrounding water bear old growth hardwood forest . Has one of the largest collections of native artifacts in the state and is available for research. Formerly named Helmer Myre State Park.
cell.text: Two islands protected from prairie fires by the surrounding water bear old growth hardwood forest . Has one of the largest collections of native artifacts in the state and is available for research. Formerly named Helmer Myre State Park.

cell.html: Preserves a remnant stand of Big Woods .
cell.text: Preserves a remnant stand of Big Woods .

cell.html: Eight buildings and structures, built by the WPA , are listed on the NRHP . Contains a steam-powered flour mill that is started up to grind flour once a year.
cell.text: Eight buildings and structures, built by the WPA , are listed on the NRHP . Contains a steam-powered flour mill that is started up to grind flour once a year.

cell.html: Red River of the North and Red Lake River
cell.text: Red River of the North and Red Lake River

cell.html: Part of the Greater Grand Forks Greenway . After the 1997 Red River Flood approximately 500 homes and buildings were removed to make way for the greenway. The Greenway serves the dual purpose of holding back river waters during floods and providing recreational opportunities.
cell.text: Part of the Greater Grand Forks Greenway . After the 1997 Red River Flood approximately 500 homes and buildings were removed to make way for the greenway. The Greenway serves the dual purpose of holding back river waters during floods and providing recreational opportunities.

cell.html: Shallow lake is a stopover for migrating waterfowl.
cell.text: Shallow lake is a stopover for migrating waterfowl.

cell.html: Originally the St. Croix Recreational Demonstration Area, the park was created from land too poor to farm. [10] It is listed as a National Historic Landmark as the largest and one of the best examples of recreational demonstration area planning during the Depression. [11]
cell.text: Originally the St. Croix Recreational Demonstration Area, the park was created from land too poor to farm. [10] It is listed as a National Historic Landmark as the largest and one of the best examples of recreational demonstration area planning during the Depression. [11]
Sakatah Lake on the Cannon River

cell.html: This parcel of hardwoods along the transition zone from forest to oak savanna was never logged.
cell.text: This parcel of hardwoods along the transition zone from forest to oak savanna was never logged.

cell.html: East and West Savanna Rivers, numerous kettle lakes
cell.text: East and West Savanna Rivers, numerous kettle lakes

cell.html: Established as a state park in 1961 to preserve the historic Savanna Portage, a difficult six-mile (10 km) trail connecting the West Savanna River and upper Mississippi River with the East Savanna River, St. Louis River, and Lake Superior. A continental divide , visible in the park, separates the West Savanna and East Savanna rivers, which flow in opposite directions.
cell.text: Established as a state park in 1961 to preserve the historic Savanna Portage, a difficult six-mile (10 km) trail connecting the West Savanna River and upper Mississippi River with the East Savanna River, St. Louis River, and Lake Superior. A continental divide , visible in the park, separates the West Savanna and East Savanna rivers, which flow in opposite directions.

cell.html: First park with a Civilian Conservation Corps camp. [12] Contains 10 CCC buildings.
cell.text: First park with a Civilian Conservation Corps camp. [12] Contains 10 CCC buildings.

cell.html: Named after Henry Rowe Schoolcraft who charted the origins of the Mississippi river with an Indian guide, Ozawindib. Contains virgin pine forest with some trees over 300 years old.
cell.text: Named after Henry Rowe Schoolcraft who charted the origins of the Mississippi river with an Indian guide, Ozawindib. Contains virgin pine forest with some trees over 300 years old.
Lake Andrew and other kettle lakes

cell.html: Named for Henry Hastings Sibley , the first governor of the state.
cell.text: Named for Henry Hastings Sibley , the first governor of the state.

cell.html: Minnesota's oldest, deepest, and richest iron mine. The tour of the mine goes 2,341 feet (714 m) below the earth's surface. Hosts the Soudan Underground Physics Laboratory High Energy Physics Lab which searches for Dark Matter .
cell.text: Minnesota's oldest, deepest, and richest iron mine. The tour of the mine goes 2,341 feet (714 m) below the earth's surface. Hosts the Soudan Underground Physics Laboratory High Energy Physics Lab which searches for Dark Matter .

cell.html: Split Rock Lake, a human-made lake, is the largest body of water in Pipestone County. This park is located on the Coteau des Prairies .
cell.text: Split Rock Lake, a human-made lake, is the largest body of water in Pipestone County. This park is located on the Coteau des Prairies .

cell.html: Lighthouse was commissioned in 1910, one of the most photographed lighthouses in the United States. Lighthouse is built on anorthosite, a remnant of ancient lava flows.
cell.text: Lighthouse was commissioned in 1910, one of the most photographed lighthouses in the United States. Lighthouse is built on anorthosite, a remnant of ancient lava flows.

cell.html: Named the Temperance River because there was no sand "bar" at its mouth.
cell.text: Named the Temperance River because there was no sand "bar" at its mouth.

cell.html: Park contains a 60 ft (18 m) tall waterfall, the tallest entirely within the state. Shovel Point and Palisade Head cliffs are popular for rock climbing.
cell.text: Park contains a 60 ft (18 m) tall waterfall, the tallest entirely within the state. Shovel Point and Palisade Head cliffs are popular for rock climbing.

cell.html: Preserves the site of the historic Yellow Medicine Agency which was destroyed in the Dakota War of 1862 .
cell.text: Preserves the site of the historic Yellow Medicine Agency which was destroyed in the Dakota War of 1862 .

cell.html: Bald eagles remain year round. With adjacent Whitewater Wildlife Management Area the park forms a flood buffer. Park is in the Driftless area
cell.text: Bald eagles remain year round. With adjacent Whitewater Wildlife Management Area the park forms a flood buffer. Park is in the Driftless area

cell.html: 45°34′05″N 92°52′33″W ﻿ / ﻿ 45.5680159 , -92.8757696 ﻿ ( Saint Croix Wild River State Park )
Named after the St. Croix's status as a National Wild and Scenic River .
cell.text: Named after the St. Croix's status as a National Wild and Scenic River .

cell.html: Provides outdoor recreation opportunities near Minneapolis-Saint Paul .
cell.text: Provides outdoor recreation opportunities near Minneapolis-Saint Paul .

cell.html: Moose and Timberwolves can be seen at the park, formerly the site of a village.
cell.text: Moose and Timberwolves can be seen at the park, formerly the site of a village.

context.text: List of Minnesota state parks - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Park Name Site County or Counties Area in acres (km ) [8] Year founded [4] Body of Water Coordinates Remarks [6]
[ edit ] List of Minnesota state parks
[ edit ] List of Minnesota state parks

Several units added to the Minnesota state park system over the years have since been redesignated or transferred to other agencies. In most cases this decision was due to the unit being too small for a state park with little chance of expansion, or largely local use rather than attracting visitors from all over the state and beyond.
In 1971 the department became the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources .

Lindbergh State Park[13]Morrison&0000000000000569.000000569 acres (2.3 km²)1931Mississippi River45°57′32″N 94°23′43″W﻿ / ﻿45.9588545, -94.3952813﻿ (Charles A Lindbergh State Park)Contains the restored home of Charles August Lindbergh, Congressman and the father of the famous aviator, Charles Lindbergh.
Crow Wing State Park[14]Crow Wing, Cass, and Morrison&0000000000003119.0000003,119 acres (12.62 km²)1959Mississippi and Crow Wing Rivers46°16′20″N 94°19′00″W﻿ / ﻿46.2722222, -94.3333333﻿ (Crow Wing State Park)Interprets the site of Old Crow Wing, an important trading settlement.
Cuyuna Country State Recreation Area[15]Crow Wing&0000000000002773.0000002,773 acres (11.22 km²)1993Chain of small lakes and streams, filled pit mines46°29′22″N 93°58′39″W﻿ / ﻿46.489550, -93.977500﻿ (Cuyuna Country State Recreation Area)The Cuyuna Range was the last of Minnesota's three major iron ranges to be discovered and mined.
Father Hennepin State Park[16]Mille Lacs&0000000000000320.000000320 acres (1.29 km²)1941Mille Lacs Lake46°08′41″N 93°29′17″W﻿ / ﻿46.1446779, -93.4880157﻿ (Father Hennepin State Park)Park is named after Father Louis Hennepin, a priest who visited the area with a French expedition in 1680.
Flandrau State Park[17]Brown&0000000000001006.0000001,006 acres (4.07 km²)1937Cottonwood River44°17′18″N 94°28′25″W﻿ / ﻿44.2882956, -94.4735837﻿ (Flandrau State Park)Park is named after Charles Eugene Flandrau, an important figure in the Battles of New Ulm during the Dakota War of 1862.
Forestville Mystery Cave State Park[18]Fillmore&0000000000003170.0000003,170 acres (12.83 km²)1963South Branch Root River and tributaries43°37′32″N 92°14′51″W﻿ / ﻿43.6255204, -92.247388﻿ (Forestville Mystery Cave State Park)Park contains Mystery Cave, the longest cave in the state that is open to the public.
Fort Ridgely State Park[19]Nicollet and Renville&0000000000001040.0000001,040 acres (4.21 km²)1911Fort Ridgely Creek44°27′09″N 94°43′51″W﻿ / ﻿44.4524621, -94.7308199﻿ (Fort Ridgely State Park)Park preserves Fort Ridgely, which is notable for its use during the Dakota War of 1862.
Fort Snelling State Park[20]Ramsey, Hennepin, and Dakota&0000000000002931.0000002,931 acres (11.86 km²)1961Mississippi and Minnesota Rivers44°53′09″N 93°10′41″W﻿ / ﻿44.8857988, -93.1779985﻿ (Fort Snelling State Park)Park contains historic Fort Snelling, which was built in 1819.
Franz Jevne State Park[21]Koochiching&0000000000000118.000000118 acres (0.48 km²)1967Rainy River48°38′32″N 94°04′50″W﻿ / ﻿48.642240, -94.080410﻿ (Franz Jevne State Park)The sons of Franz Jevne, a lawyer, offered to donate land to the state for use as a park on the condition that it be named after their father.
Frontenac State Park[22]Goodhue&0000000000002300.0000002,300 acres (9.3 km²)1957Lake Pepin on Mississippi River44°30′27″N 92°19′35″W﻿ / ﻿44.5074677, -92.3262914﻿ (Frontenac State Park)Park is home to 260 species of birds for part or all of the year.

Park is geared towards backpackers.
Glacial Lakes State Park[25]Pope&0000000000002423.0000002,423 acres (9.8 km²)1963Several kettle lakes45°32′15″N 95°31′19″W﻿ / ﻿45.537461, -95.521983﻿ (Glacial Lakes State Park)Park contains many glacial landforms, including rolling glacial hills unlike others in the state, created by the Wisconsonian glaciation.

Great River Bluffs State Park[29]Winona&0000000000003067.0000003,067 acres (12.4 km²)1971Mississippi River43°56′47″N 91°23′58″W﻿ / ﻿43.9463526, -91.3993094﻿ (Great River Bluffs State Park)Features 500-foot (150 m) high bluffs and steep "goat prairies" Formerly named O.L. Kipp State Park.
Hayes Lake State Park[30]Roseau&0000000000002958.0000002,958 acres (11.97 km²)1967Hayes Lake, North Fork Roseau River48°37′24″N 95°30′28″W﻿ / ﻿48.6233095, -95.5077539﻿ (Hayes Lake State Park)Hayes Lake was created for the park by damming the Roseau River. In the Glacial Lake Agassiz lake bed.
Hill-Annex Mine State Park[31]Itasca&0000000000000635.000000635 acres (2.57 km²)1988Filled pit mine47°19′39″N 93°16′39″W﻿ / ﻿47.327490, -93.277520﻿ (Hill-Annex Mine State Park)Well preserved historic mine buildings that are on the National Register of Historic Places
Interstate Park[32]Chisago&0000000000000298.000000298 acres (1.2 km²)1895St. Croix River45°23′42″N 92°40′11″W﻿ / ﻿45.3949622, -92.6696521﻿ (Interstate State Park)This was the first park in the United States to span two states (Minnesota and Wisconsin).
Itasca State Park[33]Hubbard, Clearwater, and Becker&0000000000032690.00000032,690 acres (132.29 km²)1891Lake Itasca47°11′51″N 95°12′07″W﻿ / ﻿47.1974579, -95.2019642﻿ (Itasca State Park)Minnesota's oldest state park. Lake Itasca is the source of the Mississippi River.
Jay Cooke State Park[34]Carlton&0000000000008781.0000008,781 acres (35.53 km²)1915Saint Louis River46°38′59″N 92°19′51″W﻿ / ﻿46.6496646, -92.330748﻿ (Jay Cooke State Park)Features rustic style historical structures and swinging bridge built by the CCC between 1933 and 1942.
John A. Latsch State Park[35]Winona&0000000000001871.0000001,871 acres (7.57 km²)1925Mississippi River44°09′43″N 91°49′20″W﻿ / ﻿44.1619082, -91.8220997﻿ (John Latsch State Park)Features three steep river bluffs named Faith, Hope, and Charity.
Judge C. R. Magney State Park[36]Cook&0000000000004643.0000004,643 acres (18.78 km²)1957Lake Superior, Brule River47°51′05″N 90°03′30″W﻿ / ﻿47.8512799, -90.0584299﻿ (Judge C R Magney State Park)Contains "Devil's Kettle" a large glacial kettle into which half of the Brule River disappears.
Kilen Woods State Park[37]Jackson&0000000000000548.000000548 acres (2.21 km²)1945Des Moines River43°43′36″N 95°03′47″W﻿ / ﻿43.7266244, -95.0630473﻿ (Killen Woods State Park)Park is on the Coteau des Prairies.
Lac qui Parle State Park[38]Lac qui Parle and Chippewa&0000000000001055.0000001,055 acres (4.26 km²)1959Lac qui Parle, Minnesota and Lac qui Parle Rivers45°01′14″N 95°53′20″W﻿ / ﻿45.0205141, -95.888921﻿ (Lac qui Parle State Park)Lac qui Parle is a widening in the Minnesota River, stopover for thousands of migrating waterfowl. Park contains 3 buildings on the NRHP.
Lake Bemidji State Park[39]Beltrami&0000000000001726.0000001,726 acres (6.98 km²)1923Lake Bemidji47°32′11″N 94°49′22″W﻿ / ﻿47.5363413, -94.8227704﻿ (Lake Bemidji State Park)In addition to recreational lakeshore, the park features a boardwalk trail out into a spruce-tamarack bog.
Lake Bronson State Park[40]Kittson&0000000000002808.0000002,808 acres (11.36 km²)1937Lake Bronson, South Branch Two Rivers48°43′29″N 96°36′12″W﻿ / ﻿48.7247004, -96.6033741﻿ (Lake Bronson State Park)Hayes lake was created for the park, by damming the Two Rivers. In the Glacial Lake Agassiz lake bed. Park is on the NRHP.
Lake Carlos State Park[41]Douglas&0000000000001236.0000001,236 acres (5.00 km²)1937Lake Carlos45°59′12″N 95°19′40″W﻿ / ﻿45.9866293, -95.3278143﻿ (Lake Carlos State Park)Five buildings on the NRHP. In a hardwood transition zone between prairies and coniferous forest.
Lake Louise State Park[42]Mower&0000000000001147.0000001,147 acres (4.64 km²)1963Lake Louise, Little Iowa River43°32′01″N 92°31′32″W﻿ / ﻿43.5335762, -92.5254538﻿ (Lake Louise State Park)Minnesota's oldest continuous recreation area. Lake Louise was created by damming the Little Iowa River.
Lake Maria State Park[43]Wright&0000000000001614.0000001,614 acres (6.53 km²)1963Several kettle lakes45°18′50″N 93°57′26″W﻿ / ﻿45.3138543, -93.9572003﻿ (Lake Maria State Park)Lightly developed to provide a wilderness area near Minneapolis-Saint Paul.
Lake Shetek State Park[44]Murray County&0000000000001108.0000001,108 acres (4.48 km²)1937Lake Shetek44°06′08″N 95°41′24″W﻿ / ﻿44.1021838, -95.6900114﻿ (Lake Shetek State Park)Eight historic resources within the state park are on the NRHP. Located on the Coteau des Prairies, the park was once treeless prairie.
Maplewood State Park[45]Otter Tail&0000000000009264.0000009,264 acres (37.49 km²)1963Several kettle lakes46°32′01″N 95°56′57″W﻿ / ﻿46.5335703, -95.9492193﻿ (Maplewood State Park)The park preserves a pre-contact habitation site that was occupied in two different periods (650–900 CE and 1450–1650) in a forest/prairie transition zone.
McCarthy Beach State Park[46]St. Louis&0000000000002471.0000002,471 acres (9.99 km²)1945Sturgeon and Side Lakes47°40′22″N 93°01′49″W﻿ / ﻿47.6727068, -93.0301834﻿ (McCarthy Beach State Park)Highways' Magazine rated the beach on Sturgeon Lake one of the top 17 beaches in North America.
Mille Lacs Kathio State Park[47]Mille Lacs&0000000000010554.00000010,554 acres (42.71 km²)1957Mille Lacs Lake, Rum River46°07′44″N 93°44′26″W﻿ / ﻿46.1288485, -93.7405269﻿ (Mille Lacs Kathio State Park)Park contains 19 identified archaeological sites. The earliest site shows evidence of copper tool manufacture. The Kathio site is a National Historic Landmark.
Minneopa State Park[48]Blue Earth&0000000000002691.0000002,691 acres (10.89 km²)1905Minnesota River, Minneopa Creek44°09′44″N 94°06′08″W﻿ / ﻿44.1621879, -94.1021803﻿ (Minneopa State Park)Contains Seppmann windmill which is on the NRHP. Minneopa Creek and its waterfalls are the major features that attract visitors.
Minnesota Valley State Recreation Area[49]Hennepin, Dakota, Scott, Carver, Sibley, and Le Sueur&0000000000005501.0000005,501 acres (22.2 km²)1969Minnesota River44°39′43″N 93°42′12″W﻿ / ﻿44.661999, -93.703337﻿ (Minnesota Valley State Recreation Area)The sections of this non-contiguous park are interspersed with units of the Minnesota Valley National Wildlife Refuge in the valley formed by Glacial River Warren.
Monson Lake State Park[50]Swift County&0000000000000187.000000187 acres (0.75 km²)1937Monson and West Sunberg Lakes45°19′14″N 95°16′30″W﻿ / ﻿45.3205175, -95.2750235﻿ (Monson Lake Memorial State Park)Established as a memorial to settlers who died in the Dakota War of 1862.
Moose Lake State Park[51]Carlton&0000000000001199.0000001,199 acres (4.85 km²)1971Moosehead and Echo Lakes46°26′11″N 92°43′31″W﻿ / ﻿46.436319, -92.72521﻿ (Moose Lake State Park)The Moose Lake Agate and Geological Interpretive Center is located in the park. Contains an exhibition of Minnesota's state gemstone, the Lake Superior agate, and contains displays on rocks, minerals and geology of Minnesota.
Myre-Big Island State Park[52]Freeborn&0000000000002028.0000002,028 acres (8.2 km²)1947Albert Lea Lake43°37′26″N 93°17′21″W﻿ / ﻿43.6238465, -93.2890959﻿ (Myre-Big Island State Park)Two islands protected from prairie fires by the surrounding water bear old growth hardwood forest. Has one of the largest collections of native artifacts in the state and is available for research. Formerly named Helmer Myre State Park.
Nerstrand-Big Woods State Park[53]Rice&0000000000002882.0000002,882 acres (11.6 km²)1945Prairie Creek44°20′43″N 93°06′27″W﻿ / ﻿44.3452425, -93.1074337﻿ (Nerstrand Big Woods State Park)Preserves a remnant stand of Big Woods.
Old Mill State Park[54]Marshall&0000000000000287.000000287 acres (1.16 km²)1951Middle River48°21′41″N 96°34′13″W﻿ / ﻿48.361364, -96.5703288﻿ (Old Mill State Park)Eight buildings and structures, built by the WPA, are listed on the NRHP. Contains a steam-powered flour mill that is started up to grind flour once a year.
Red River State Recreation Area[55]Polk&0000000000001230.0000001,230 acres (4.97 km²)1997Red River of the North and Red Lake River47°55′58″N 97°02′08″W﻿ / ﻿47.9327778, -97.0355556﻿ (Red River State Recreation Area)Part of the Greater Grand Forks Greenway. After the 1997 Red River Flood approximately 500 homes and buildings were removed to make way for the greenway. The Greenway serves the dual purpose of holding back river waters during floods and providing recreational opportunities.
Rice Lake State Park[56]Steele and Dodge&0000000000001071.0000001,071 acres (4.3 km²)1963Rice Lake44°05′15″N 93°03′41″W﻿ / ﻿44.0874639, -93.061315﻿ (Rice Lake State Park)Shallow lake is a stopover for migrating waterfowl.
Saint Croix State Park[57]Pine County&0000000000033895.00000033,895 acres (137.16 km²)1943St. Croix River45°58′27″N 92°35′01″W﻿ / ﻿45.9741154, -92.5835304﻿ (Saint Croix State Park)Originally the St. Croix Recreational Demonstration Area, the park was created from land too poor to farm.[10] It is listed as a National Historic Landmark as the largest and one of the best examples of recreational demonstration area planning during the Depression.[11]
Sakatah Lake State Park[58]Le Sueur and Rice&0000000000000842.000000842 acres (3.4 km²)1963Sakatah Lake on the Cannon River44°13′16″N 93°32′09″W﻿ / ﻿44.2210746, -93.5357792﻿ (Sakatah State Park)This parcel of hardwoods along the transition zone from forest to oak savanna was never logged.
Savanna Portage State Park[59]Aitkin and St. Louis&0000000000015818.00000015,818 acres (64.01 km²)1961East and West Savanna Rivers, numerous kettle lakes46°50′15″N 93°09′24″W﻿ / ﻿46.8374455, -93.1566054﻿ (Savanna Portage State Park)Established as a state park in 1961 to preserve the historic Savanna Portage, a difficult six-mile (10 km) trail connecting the West Savanna River and upper Mississippi River with the East Savanna River, St. Louis River, and Lake Superior. A continental divide, visible in the park, separates the West Savanna and East Savanna rivers, which flow in opposite directions.
Scenic State Park[60]Itasca&0000000000003360.0000003,360 acres (13.59 km²)1921Sandwick and Coon Lakes47°42′57″N 93°33′47″W﻿ / ﻿47.7157733, -93.5629701﻿ (Scenic State Park)First park with a Civilian Conservation Corps camp.[12] Contains 10 CCC buildings.
Schoolcraft State Park[61]Cass and Itasca&0000000000000225.000000225 acres (0.91 km²)1959Mississippi River47°13′30″N 93°47′60″W﻿ / ﻿47.2249502, -93.7999449﻿ (Schoolcraft State Park)Named after Henry Rowe Schoolcraft who charted the origins of the Mississippi river with an Indian guide, Ozawindib. Contains virgin pine forest with some trees over 300 years old.
Sibley State Park[62]Kandiyohi&0000000000002509.0000002,509 acres (10.15 km²)1919Lake Andrew and other kettle lakes45°19′11″N 95°01′23″W﻿ / ﻿45.3196867, -95.0230696﻿ (Sibley State Park)Named for Henry Hastings Sibley, the first governor of the state.
Soudan Underground Mine State Park[63]St. Louis&0000000000001250.0000001,250 acres (5.05 km²)1963Lake Vermilion47°49′29″N 92°15′23″W﻿ / ﻿47.8246403, -92.2562691﻿ (Soudan Underground Mine State Park)Minnesota's oldest, deepest, and richest iron mine. The tour of the mine goes 2,341 feet (714 m) below the earth's surface. Hosts the Soudan Underground Physics Laboratory High Energy Physics Lab which searches for Dark Matter.
Split Rock Creek State Park[64]Pipestone&0000000000001303.0000001,303 acres (5.27 km²)1937Split Rock Lake43°53′53″N 96°21′51″W﻿ / ﻿43.8980264, -96.3642032﻿ (Split Rock Creek State Park)Split Rock Lake, a human-made lake, is the largest body of water in Pipestone County. This park is located on the Coteau des Prairies.
Split Rock Lighthouse State Park[65]Lake&0000000000002200.0000002,200 acres (8.9 km²)1945Lake Superior47°11′32″N 91°23′35″W﻿ / ﻿47.1921472, -91.3929484﻿ (Split Rock Lighthouse State Park)Lighthouse was commissioned in 1910, one of the most photographed lighthouses in the United States. Lighthouse is built on anorthosite, a remnant of ancient lava flows.
Temperance River State Park[66]Cook&0000000000005059.0000005,059 acres (20.47 km²)1957Lake Superior and Temperance River47°33′16″N 90°52′21″W﻿ / ﻿47.5543466, -90.8723722﻿ (Temperance River State Park)Named the Temperance River because there was no sand "bar" at its mouth.
Tettegouche State Park[67]Lake&0000000000009562.0000009,562 acres (38.69 km²)1979Lake Superior and Baptism River47°21′32″N 91°15′51″W﻿ / ﻿47.358806, -91.2640506﻿ (Tettegouche State Park)Park contains a 60 ft (18 m) tall waterfall, the tallest entirely within the state. Shovel Point and Palisade Head cliffs are popular for rock climbing.
Upper Sioux Agency State Park[68]Yellow Medicine&0000000000001281.0000001,281 acres (5.18 km²)1963Minnesota and Yellow Medicine Rivers44°44′17″N 95°27′14″W﻿ / ﻿44.7380132, -95.4539039﻿ (Upper Sioux Agency State Park)Preserves the site of the historic Yellow Medicine Agency which was destroyed in the Dakota War of 1862.
Whitewater State Park[69]Winona&0000000000002745.0000002,745 acres (11.1 km²)1919Whitewater River44°03′30″N 92°03′32″W﻿ / ﻿44.058297, -92.0587726﻿ (Whitewater State Park)Bald eagles remain year round. With adjacent Whitewater Wildlife Management Area the park forms a flood buffer. Park is in the Driftless area
Wild River State Park[70]Chisago&0000000000006767.0000006,767 acres (27.38 km²)1973St. Croix River45°34′05″N 92°52′33″W﻿ / ﻿45.5680159, -92.8757696﻿ (Saint Croix Wild River State Park)Named after the St. Croix's status as a National Wild and Scenic River.
William O'Brien State Park[71]Washington&0000000000001620.0000001,620 acres (6.55 km²)1947St. Croix River45°13′10″N 92°45′58″W﻿ / ﻿45.2194109, -92.7660423﻿ (William O'Brien State Park)Provides outdoor recreation opportunities near Minneapolis-Saint Paul.
Zippel Bay State Park[72]Lake of the Woods&0000000000002906.0000002,906 acres (11.76 km²)1959Lake of the Woods48°51′50″N 94°51′34″W﻿ / ﻿48.8638742, -94.8593862﻿ (Zippel Bay State Park)Moose and Timberwolves can be seen at the park, formerly the site of a village.
